item.title: SA warned complacency could undo the good
item.description: Competency has once again been stressed by health officials, asking South Australians 'not to undo all the good'.

item.title: Virus ‘hat-trick’ for WA with no new cases
item.description: Western Australia has started manufacturing its own protective face shields for health workers as the state marked a third straight day of no new coronavirus cases.

item.title: Prospect of beer and footy edges closer
item.description: The prospect of a visit to the pub to watch a game of footy is seemingly edging ever closer as some states start to ease restrictions and the national cabinet prepares to consider lifting some broader curbs next week.

item.title: Cold, windy blast hits Tasmania
item.description: Wild weather is set to ease after a cold blast brought snow and damaging winds to Tasmania.

item.title: NSW could abolish stamp duty, payroll tax
item.description: The NSW opposition have given their cautious support to the Berejiklian government's push to abolish stamp duty and payroll tax in a bid to revive the state's economy following coronavirus.

item.title: Health authorities probe Newmarch lapse
item.description: NSW health authorities are investigating possible infection control breaches by staff of a Sydney aged care facility at the centre of a coronavirus cluster.

item.title: COVID outbreak at Melbourne meat facility
item.description: A coronavirus cluster has been uncovered at a Melbourne meat processor, amid warnings Victoria's progress against the pandemic remains "incredibly fragile".

item.title: Singapore to ease some virus restrictions
item.description: Singapore will start easing some curbs put in place to contain the spread of the coronavirus over the next few weeks, Health Minister Gan Kim Yong says.

item.title: SA’s economic pain from COVID-19: report
item.description: The COVID-19 pandemic will impact South Australia's economy and jobs until 2024, with double-digit unemployment, a plunge in Gross State Product and a slow recovery predicted in a new report.

item.title: Hong Kong police clear May Day protest
item.description: Hong Kong police have used pepper spray to disperse more than 100 protesters singing and chanting pro-democracy slogans in a shopping mall.
